Penn Badgley and wife Domino Kirke nearly split after suffering two devastating miscarriages
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-11-18 02:37:00

Penn Badgley and his wife, Domino Kirke, almost separated following two devastating miscarriages. The “You” star detailed the losses in his new book of essays “Crushmore: Essays on Love, Loss, and Coming-of-Age.” “This was our second loss together. A time when it did not feel as though the cycle would break,” he wrote. “My wife and I neared separation as many do after losses like that.” He added that the separation largely came about because the couple felt “isolated” in dealing with the losses because we live in a “culture that doesn't talk much about these things or know how to support those going through it.” Badgley, 39, added, “Seeing our still baby in that tripped out black-and-white sono imagery is a dreadful memory I can't shake every time we go for a sonogram now.” He reiterated the need for openness and talking more about miscarriages on the “Totally Booked” podcast on Sunday. “That sort of loss is really common, and we should — I don't know if talking about it alone is what we need,” he said. “We at least need to start by talking about it more … They do happen all the time, and they can be really, really painful. Well, I would say they universally are painful. Maybe not everybody's fully allowed to feel that way.” Though it's unclear when the miscarriages occurred, the actor and Kirke, 41, are parents to son James, whom they welcomed in August 2020. Additionally, Kirke gave birth to twin sons in September When Kirke announced she was pregnant in February, she admitted to being “stunned” via an Instagram announcement. “Spontaneous twins are beyond magical,” she wrote at the time. Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? Kirke is also the mother to a son named Cassius from a previous relationship. “It's funny because I wrote this before the twins were born, and now I feel like I am — and I mean this with love — but I feel like I'm drowning in children,” Badgley said on the podcast. “So, it's harder to get in touch with that feeling of loss because my cup truly runneth over.” The “Gossip Girl” alum shared that he was grateful that he and Kirke didn't give in to the “gravity” of separating. Kirke and Badgley started dating in 2014 and tied the knot in February 2017 at a New York courthouse. They exchanged vows once again that June.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Christopher Nolan finally figures out "usable sound" for The Odyssey
Source: AV Club    Published: 2025-11-18 02:24:00

In what appears to be a career first for Christopher Nolan, the Oscar-winning filmmaker claims his upcoming adaptation of Homer's epic, The Odyssey, features “usable sound.” Taking after one of his cinematic heroes, Michael Mann, Nolan has long been a proponent of having his characters mumble through scenes as large bombs and engines muddy up the mix. Since the director prefers shooting on large-format film, which requires a noisy, cumbersome camera, and refuses to re-record audio during post-production, incoherent dialogue has since become a hallmark of Nolan's auteurism. That was until science finally caught up with the director. IMAX recently developed “the blimp,” a casing for its cameras that reduces camera noise, allowing Nolan to record clean audio, to the delight of his massive viewership, which spends a good portion of his movies wondering what that guy just said. Despite “the blimp” being essentially the same technique filmmakers used in the 1930s as talkies took over, Nolan called the technology “a game-changer.” “You can be shooting a foot from [an actor's] face while they're whispering and get usable sound,” Nolan tells Empire. “What that opens up are intimate moments of performance on the world's most beautiful format.” Nolan did not specify whether “blimp” technology could adequately capture the dulcet tones of Tom Hardy speaking through a mask with the same clarity. In addition to coherent line readings, Nolan also promises he didn't break a single IMAX camera on the set of The Odyssey. “I did not destroy an IMAX camera on this film,” Nolan says. “I have destroyed several in my time, but these ones survived The Odyssey.” Usable sound? Unbroken IMAX cameras? Has Christopher Nolan lost his edge? Odyssey star and certified “that guy” James Remar recently indicated that he has not. Speaking to The Hollywood Reporter, Remar tacitly confirmed that Nolan's long-running feud with chairs and cellphones on set continues unabated. “No cell phones on set, and the man never sits down,” he said. “He stands next to the camera for every single shot. He did that in Iceland, too. We were on the beach shooting in Iceland; I never saw him sit down once for 12 hours out there. Every single day. It was freezing. Everybody was freezing.” GET A.V.CLUB RIGHT IN YOUR INBOX Pop culture obsessives writing for the pop culture obsessed. Sign Up Editors' Picks The 35 Best Anime of All Time By Austin Jones November 12, 2025 | 4:25pm Jesus Christ, The Carpenter's Son is bland Biblical horror By Jacob Oller November 11, 2025 | 5:00pm Why isn't IT from IT: Welcome To Derry actually scary? By William Hughes November 9, 2025 | 10:00pm © 2025 Paste Media Group. All Rights Reserved

Here Are All of Taylor Swift's Title Tracks, Ranked (Critic's Picks)
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-11-18 01:37:12

Swift recorded namesake songs for seven of her 12 studio albums. By Denise Warner With 12 full-lengths under her belt, Taylor Swift has released seven albums that include songs that reflect each album's name: “Fearless,” “Speak Now,” “Red,” “Lover,” “evermore,” “The Tortured Poets Department” and “The Life of a Showgirl.” Right now, only three – “Fearless,” “Red” and “Lover” – became official singles. The rest linger in the deep cuts, but certainly fan favorites, of her work. Spanning her career from 2008's Fearless to 2025's The Life of a Showgirl – currently enjoying its sixth week atop the Billboard 200 – her title tracks show the breadth and depth of her sonic evolution, from her country roots to her pop superstardom, with her signature storytelling lyricism on display. (And don't worry about the five albums without a title track: She shows them love in other ways. Debut doesn't mention her name, but she later shouts herself out on both “22” from Red and “Clara Bow” from The Tortured Poets Department; 1989 never received a lyrical callback, but her famous introduction to its world tour does: “My name is Taylor and I was born in 1989!”; Reputation tracks “End Game” and “Delicate” as well as Speak Now's “Superman” reference reputation; evermore's “gold rush” includes “My mind turns your life into folklore”; and mentions of midnight abound throughout her catalog, but only “Anti-Hero” and “Midnight Rain” from Midnights and Rep's “New Year's Day” contain the actual word.)Read below for Billboard's ranking of the seven title tracks, as well as their peaks on the Billboard Hot 100. (And check out all of her lead singles ranked and her biggest Billboard hits too.) Year: 2020Hot 100 Peak: 57 The album's closer – exclusive of the deluxe version – offers a piano-laden ballad of heartbreak and confusion (“I replay my footsteps on each stepping stone / Trying to find the one where I went wrong / Writing letters / Addressed to the fire,” Swift sings) with Justin Vernon's angsty falsetto floating through the bridge. It's a gorgeous duet held back only by their superior pairing on “exile” and its quieter existence in the Swift universe. Year: 2025Hot 100 Peak: 8 The grandiose duet reflects on fame and what it takes to rise – and stay on top. “I took her pearls of wisdom, hung them from my neck / I paid my dues with every bruise, I knew what to expect,” Swift states proudly. “Do you wanna take a skate on the ice inside my veins? / They ripped me off like false lashes and then threw me away,” Carpenter lilts with a sweet but vicious edge. Year: 2010, 2023 (Taylor's Version)Hot 100 Peak: 8, 33 Swift expertly captures the panic of watching someone walk down the aisle to the wrong person in the emotionally charged “Speak Now.” “There's a silence, there's my last chance / I stand up with shaky hands, all eyes on me / Horrified looks from everyone in the room / But I'm only lookin' at you,” she sings with a baited apprehension on the country-rock tune. Year: 2019Hot 100 Peak: 10 On the tender and romantic serenade – perfect for a wedding day dance – Swift professes her desire to capture a partner's heart “forever and ever.” Despite the overlying tension of the questions: “Can I go where you go? Can we always be this close?,” the beauty of the deeply confessional rumination rings true. Year: 2008, 2021 (Taylor's Version)Hot 100 Peak: 9, 71 All the feelings of the rush of a first romance that makes you brave, this country sparkler dazzles in its earnest recounting of what makes young love so powerful. “And I don't know how it gets better than this / You take my hand and drag me head first, fearless / And I don't know but with you, I'd dance / In a storm in my best dress, fearless,” she chants boldly. Year: 2024Hot 100 Peak: 4 Rife with modern-day imagery (“You smoked then ate seven bars of chocolate / We declared Charlie Puth should be a bigger artist”) and flush with the anxiety of a fleeting relationship, Swift swells to an uneasy admission: “And who's gonna hold you, like me?” As she says, “No f—ing body.” Year: 2012, 2021 (Taylor's Version)Hot 100 Peak: 6, 25 An anthemic mix of guitars and banjos with an outsized synth-pop overlay, Taylor wrenches open her feelings and lets them free on “Red” – a poetic masterpiece of frenzied, colorful passion. “Losing him was blue, like I'd never known / Missing him was dark gray, all alone / Forgetting him was like trying to know somebody you never met / But loving him was red,” she sings. Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Billboard is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Billboard Media, LLC. All Rights Reserved.

‘That ‘70s Show' star Danny Masterson blames lawyer in fight to overturn rape conviction
Source: Page Six    Published: 2025-11-18 01:34:00

Danny Masterson is blaming his lawyer for failing to summon key witnesses during his 2023 rape trial as he tries to overturn his conviction. According to new court documents obtained by Page Six, the “That '70s Show” alum claims his attorney Philip Cohen — who took over for the actor's former lawyer due to scheduling issues — only questioned two out of potentially “more than 20 potential witnesses” that could've spoken in his defense. Per the filing, Cohen allegedly didn't attempt to contact the witnesses, who he claimed had given “prior statements to the police and to investigators.” Advertisement Masterson also alleges in the docs that Cohen chose not to refute the prosecutor's allegations about Scientology. Advertisement Among the allegations was that the church threatens women if they report high-profile members to authorities. Masterson claims in the filing that Cohen was advised by attorneys for the Church of Scientology to call members to fight back against the allegations, but he allegedly failed to do so. Per the filing, “the jury saw only the tip of the iceberg of available defense evidence in the form of the complaining witnesses' inconsistent statements while the wealth of directly exculpatory evidence went unused for no viable tactical reason.” Advertisement Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? Cohen wasn't immediately available to Page Six for comment. Masterson was arrested in June 2020 on three charges of rape that occurred between 2001 and 2003. Advertisement While the actor pleaded not guilty in January 2021, he was found guilty of raping two of three women in May 2023. Start your day with Page Six Daily. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Want celebrity news as it breaks? Masterson was sentenced to 30 years to life in prison and is currently serving time at the California Men's Colony facility. In December 2024, the “Ranch” alum appealed his conviction, arguing that there were several errors in his trial, which violated his “rights to confrontation and a fair trial.” Amid his ongoing legal proceedings, Masterson's ex Bijou Phillips filed for divorce in September 2023 shortly after his sentencing. Advertisement The actress had notably stood by Masterson's side throughout the trial, though an insider previously told People that she went through “a very difficult time” after his conviction. At the time, Masterson agreed to give Phillips full custody of their daughter, Fianna Francis. Most recently, Phillip requested to remove his last name from the 11-year-old's surname last month.

Live-action Moana teaser clears low bar of featuring flesh-and-blood humans
Source: AV Club    Published: 2025-11-18 01:01:00

Moana is the latest Disney Vault escapee to receive the obligatory “live-action remake” treatment, and to its credit, the trailer does contain live-action elements. Moana, for one, as played by Catherine Laga'aia, taking over for Auli'i Cravalho, who voiced the character in the two animated versions, is a flesh-and-blood human. That's more than we can say for Dwayne Johnson's Maui, who we only get a look at from the back. The sand and, occasionally, water look real, too. Still, released earlier today, the teaser features more “photorealistic” versions of cartoon characters that looked better in their natural, animated state. ﻿ Aside from the cynical calculations of charging audiences twice for the same movie, the obvious hit on these remakes, notably the billion-dollar-grossing Lion King and its all-but-forgotten follow-up, Moufasa (which only made $720 million), is that they aren't that live-action. In fact, one could say they're 3-D animated movies. But the speed at which animated classics become live-action advertisements for the animated film on Disney+ is ramping up, too. At least Lilo & Stitch took 25 years to reach the remake stage. In contrast, the original Moana came out less than a decade ago. If the last year is any indication, Disney might stop trying so hard to remake its golden-era classics, like Snow White and Pinocchio, and stick to its recent output, especially as it runs out of Disney Renaissance titles to reinterpret. Despite all the finger-pointing at Rachel Zegler, Snow White's failure has more to do with the fact that the kids aren't as familiar with 1939's Snow White, and the parents bringing them have more nostalgia for The Little Mermaid than the magic mirror. The same might be true for Pinocchio and Peter Pan & Wendy, which vanished onto Disney+ after reportedly costing more than $150 million each. Given how well Moana 2, a TV show forced into movie shape, and Lilo & Stitch, a TV-movie that became Hollywood's only billion-dollar grosser of the year, it's fair to anticipate another quick payday for the Mouse House. We're still waiting to see one we like, though. Thus far, none of Disney's “live-action remakes” has generated better than a C+ from The A.V. Club‘s critics. Moana opens on July 10, 2026. ‘Come See Me in the Good Light' Review: Doc Tenderly Traces Poet Andrea Gibson's Final Year of Life and Love
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-11-18 00:17:04

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Chronicling the Colorado poet laureate's relationship, work and battle with cancer, Ryan White's Sundance-premiering film is available to stream on Apple TV. By Jourdain Searles If there's one thing audiences will get from Ryan White's new documentary Come See Me in the Good Light, it's that it's a truly beautiful love story. Poets Andrea Gibson and Megan Falley found each other through the beauty of words and honest, emotional expression. Their life together in Colorado is full of friends, fun and humor. In an increasingly hostile world, these two queer people were able to carve out an existence for themselves that is happy and authentic to them. Andrea and Megan are gentle with each other throughout the film, even as it becomes clear that cancer puts an expiration date on their domestic bliss. Related Stories Music New Documentary Pulls the Curtain Back on Famed L.A. Rocker Hangout the Sunset Marquis Business An Ad Tier for Apple TV? The Tech Giant Buying Warner Bros.? Don't Bet on It, Eddy Cue Says Andrea died in July of this year in Megan's arms, a devastating ending to their story. Come See Me in the Good Light (available on Apple TV) premiered at Sundance several months before and thankfully, Andrea was able to see it on the big screen. It's difficult to imagine what it must have felt like to watch their whole life in living color, already knowing that it was likely going to end. Come See Me in the Good Light The Bottom Line Earns your tears. Release date: Friday, Nov. 14 (Apple TV)Featuring: Andrea Gibson, Megan FalleyDirector: Ryan White 1 hour 49 minutes It takes incredible strength to embark on making a film while one's health is deteriorating rapidly. And yet Andrea is a delightful and funny presence onscreen, whether they're trying to fix their broken mailbox, working on a poem or just joking around with Megan. Andrea's sincerity and fearlessness serves to lighten the heaviness of their story. We quickly learn that Andrea has ovarian cancer and are forced to watch their body deteriorate before our eyes. But thankfully Andrea's spirit remains intact as they tell the story of their life and their journey with spoken word poetry. Their poems are simple in language with an undeniable emotional complexity, vulnerably embracing sentiment. A chunk of the film focuses on Andrea's desire to perform spoken word poetry on stage in front of a crowd one last time. When we finally see them take the stage, it's a moving, triumphant moment. Come See Me in the Good Light is relentlessly emotional and intentionally uplifting, with an intimate quality that makes it feel like a home movie. We are rarely treated to such an affectionate portrait of a treasured queer artist embracing the last days of their life with a loving spouse. Knowing how personal the project was to everyone involved — from participants to producers and even the director — wraps the whole film in a palpable sense of warmth. These circumstances make the doc difficult to evaluate in any objective sense — it's a wonder that it was made at all, and so tenderly. White skillfully captures a portrait of a queer poet who wanted the world to know how much they loved and were loved by those around them. It's an unapologetically sentimental film, knowingly pulling at every single heartstring, encouraging us to open up the emotional floodgates and give ourselves over to Andrea's resilient positivity. Come See Me in the Good Light wants to be life-affirming more than anything else, especially for artists in queer and marginalized communities. The streaming era has not been kind to intimate documentaries like these, buried under mountains of flashier content. Andrea hoped the film would help people in the future, and there's no doubt that it will, as long as they know where to find it. Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

Congress Is Voting on Whether to Release the Epstein Files. Here's What to Know
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-11-18 00:00:00

By Nikki McCann Ramirez After months of delay tactics and attempted strong-arming by Republican leadership, the House is set to vote Tuesday on legislation that would force the Justice Department to release the so-called Epstein files. The vote, which is expected to pass with the support of over a dozen Republicans, marks a bipartisan rejection of President Donald Trump, who urged his party to move on from Epstein and vote against the resolution before reversing course over the weekend after it had become clear the resolution would pass. This historic vote — and the months-long battle to bring the bill to the floor — caused rifts between Trump and some of his closest allies, while continuing to raise questions about the president's relationship with one of the most notorious sex offenders in American history. As lawmakers prepare to cast their ballots, here's everything you need to know about what they will actually be voting on, what is already public, and what questions they hope to answer by releasing new information. Popular on Rolling Stone The documents referred to as the “Epstein files” are the evidence and testimony collected by the Justice Department and FBI over the course of two investigations and criminal cases against Epstein. Epstein pleaded guilty in 2008 to procuring and soliciting prostitution from a minor in a controversial sweetheart deal with federal prosecutors. He died by suicide in federal custody in 2019 after being charged with sex trafficking of minors in a separate investigation. The files held by the DOJ and FBI reportedly contain thousands of pages of witness and survivor testimony, digital evidence, communications between Epstein and others, as well as potentially videos and images of sexual abuse against minors. Since Epstein died in prison, only his close associate and long term partner — Ghislane Maxwell — has been tried and convicted in connection with the trafficking ring run by Epstein. The lack of subsequent investigations and prosecutions into others named by survivors as participants in their abuse has generated widespread public interest in the contents of the files, and the reasons behind federal prosecutors' failure to pursue additional indictments. Editor's picks The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time Conservatives and right-wing commentators spent years calling for transparency regarding the government's Epstein investigations, while insisting Trump would release the files upon returning to office. In July, after a public stunt in which prominent MAGA influencers were photographed at the White House with binders supposedly containing a portion of the files, the DOJ and FBI pulled the rug out from under their own movement, announcing that they would not be releasing any additional indictments, and that evidence related to the case would not be made public. The resulting backlash has persisted for months, and the slow, continuous trickle of information related to the case has placed increased scrutiny on the president. Shortly after the DOJ made its announcement, The Wall Street Journal reported that Trump had been warned by the Justice Department that his name appears in the files. Trump has repeatedly called the scandal a “hoax” perpetrated by Democrats. On Saturday, he demanded that Attorney General Pam Bondi launch investigations into other men named in Epstein-related documents, including former President Bill Clinton, former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, and LinkedIn founder Reid Hoffman. Bondi quickly agreed. The House will vote Tuesday on “The Epstein Files Transparency Act,” which would require the DOJ to release “all unclassified records, documents, communications, and investigative materials in the possession of the Department of Justice, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation and United States Attorneys' Offices,” related to the cases against Epstein and Maxwell. These include flight logs and travel records, records on corporate entities associated with Epstein, the identities of individuals “named or referenced in connection with Epstein's criminal activities, civil settlements, immunity or plea agreements, or investigatory proceedings,” as well as internal communications among government agents discussing the case. Related Content FCC Chairman Shares Trump Post Calling for NBC to Fire Seth Meyers ‘Immediately' The War Between MTG and Trump: How Did We Get Here? Aaron Sorkin on Writing Presidents and America's ‘Cult-Like Devotion' to Trump 'SNL' Weekend Update Hammers Trump Over Epstein The act would allow the DOJ to redact sensitive information pertaining to the identity of survivors, as well as material depicting child sexual abuse, other violent crimes, or material that would jeopardize an ongoing investigation. Critically, there is some evidence in the DOJ's documents on Epstein that cannot be released without judicial approval, primarily sealed grand jury transcripts. Judges have recently rejected bids by the DOJ to unseal grand jury testimony related to Epstein's case, although it is not unheard of for transcripts to be made public. So, if Congress has to force the DOJ to release all these materials, where are things like Trump's page from Epstein's “birthday book,” and the Epstein emails released earlier this month coming from? They're from an entirely separate source: the Epstein estate. Democrats on the House Oversight Committee, led by Rep. Robert Garcia (D-Calif.), have been working with Epstein's estate, as well as survivors, to release evidentiary documents held by representatives of the late sex offender. These include the so-called “birthday book” — a collection of over 50 congratulatory letters that included a lewd missive from Trump — and thousands of emails between Epstein, Maxwell, and other individuals the Oversight Committee released last week. The trove of over 20,000 emails included allegations that Trump knew of Epstein's activities with underage girls. Epstein wrote in 2011 that Trump “spent hours” at his house with one of his victims, said he was the man who could “take down” Trump, and described Trump as “the dog that hasn't barked.”In another email, Epstein tells a reporter to look into reports that Trump was so enthralled while ogling young women in Epstein's pool that he ran face-first into a glass door. On Sunday, Garcia appeared on MS NOW and reaffirmed that the Oversight Committee will continue to seek additional materials from the Epstein estate and other sources. “What we've received pales in comparison to the documents that actually exist in the Department of Justice,” he said. “Just stay tuned, because there's a lot more information that is going to be released, more documents that we're going to get, and we're going to continue to demand that they do the right thing and get us that release from the Department of Justice.” Trump again accused Democrats on Sunday of pushing the “Epstein Hoax” as a way to “deflect from all of their bad policies and losses.” “Epstein was a Democrat, and he is the Democrat's problem, not the Republican's problem! Ask Bill Clinton, Reid Hoffman, and Larry Summers about Epstein, they know all about him, don't waste your time with Trump,” he wrote. Hours later, Trump flipped his position on the vote, writing on Truth Social that “Republicans should vote to release the Epstein files, because we have nothing to hide, and it's time to move on from this Democrat Hoax.” The 180 came after Trump's efforts to kill the discharge petition — the mechanism through which House members are able to force a vote on the files over the objections of leadership — failed. Last week, the White House reportedly summoned Rep. Lauren Boebert (D-Colo.) to the Situation Room and attempted to convince her to remove her name from the petition, a similar unsuccessful effort was made to convince Rep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.) to withdraw her support. Trending Stories Elon Musk Fires Back After Billie Eilish Calls Him a ‘Coward' for Wealth Hoarding Jon Stewart Questions Trump References in Epstein Emails: ‘Which Bubba Was He Blowing?' Selena Quintanilla's Autopsy Report Revealed 30 Years After Her Death ‘Weird Al' Yankovic Announces 90-Date ‘Bigger & Weirder' 2026 Tour Now that Trump says he's supportive of the petition, it bears remembering that — just as he can order the DOJ to investigate his political rivals — he could order Bondi to release the files without the intervention of Congress. Like any other bill, it will be sent up to the Senate, where — if leadership decides to bring it to a vote — it would require only a simple majority to pass. It would then head to Trump's desk. The president has already indicated he would sign the bill if it does. “I'm all for it,” he said as part of his response to a question on Monday about whether he'd sign the bill. We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. © 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


OTHER

Theatre Review: "Paranormal Activity" Takes Live Theater to Scary New Heights
Source: We Live Entertainment    Published: 2025-11-18 18:54:13

The iconic horror franchise gets a theatrical makeover in the spooky stage play Paranormal Activity. This new story mirrors the style, structure, and escalating dread of the six-film series. But make no mistake: while there's an emotional spine holding the narrative together, it's the special effects designed by illusionist Chris Fisher (the mastermind behind the jaw-dropping moments in Stranger Things: The First Shadow and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child) that audiences will be buzzing about long after they've exited the theater. This production is built on “how did they do THAT?” energy, and it delivers. The plot centers on Lou (Cher Alvarez) and James (Patrick Heusinger), an American couple who've just relocated to London for James's job. They've been placed in a lovely craftsman-style home, the sort of quaint London dwelling that practically begs to be haunted. And as far as Lou is concerned, there's already enough to deal with. They're putting an ocean between themselves and James's mother, Carolanne, played by Shannon Cochran, with an enjoyably meddling edge. (And yes, naming her after “Carolanne” is a delightful wink to Poltergeist.) Carolanne's anxiety isn't entirely unwarranted. There's a history with Lou's mental health, a series of incidents back in Chicago that still cast a shadow. But Lou insists she's fine, and for a brief moment, the newly arrived couple actually believes they're about to embark on a fresh start. Then the creepy stuff begins. At first, it's the small things: power outages, water faucets turning on by themselves, doors that refuse to stay closed. But as Lou becomes convinced something supernatural is inside the house – and as James tries very, very hard to be the rational one – the audience watches their grip on reality begin to slip. Once James finally accepts that something is happening, they call in the wonderfully quirky ghost-hunting podcaster Etheline Cotgrave (Kate Fry). Let's just say her visit doesn't go well, and the haunting escalates into a full-force assault. Along the way, the couple's buried secrets snap to the surface, offering clues to who or what might be tormenting their home. To be clear, the story of Paranormal Activity isn't breaking new ground. A couple moves into a house. Weird things occur. Trauma resurfaces. Something sinister demands attention. It's Horror 101. But seeing this kind of story unfold live gives it a fresh charge. One of the defining traits of the films is the found-footage style that encourages audiences to scan every corner for a flicker of movement. The stage production cleverly replicates that feeling. With Gareth Fry's sound design building the franchise's signature low, ominous rumble (the audio clue that a scare is coming), the entire house set becomes a minefield of suspense. The two-story design ensures the audience's eyes are constantly darting, trying to anticipate which hallway, staircase, or shadowy nook will erupt next. And many of those moments truly land. The audience I saw it with screamed, gasped, clutched strangers, and occasionally laughed just to release the tension. I won't spoil a single effect, but several of them are as impressive as anything I've seen in a Broadway-scale thriller. As directed by Felix Barrett (Sleep No More) and restaged by the show's playwright Levi Holloway (The Grey House), the pacing is tight, the atmosphere immersive, and the commitment to the franchise's tone surprisingly faithful. There are, however, a few drawbacks. The actors' volume is often so low that major plot points get swallowed, perhaps intentionally, to make the audience lean in before a scare hits with a jump-worthy jolt. Effective, yes, but occasionally frustrating. (This tactic was used purposely in the horror classic The Exorcist.) The second act is also dimly lit to the point of murkiness, which contributes to the mood but sometimes makes it difficult to see who's where and what's happening. Still, those issues don't sink the production. If anything, they feel like growing pains for a show experimenting with how far live theater can push 21st-century horror. And as someone who genuinely loves the Paranormal Activity films, I wasn't convinced the franchise would translate to a stage. Turns out, it absolutely does. For fans of the movies, this is a must-see. For theatergoers looking for something different, atmospheric, and seasonally spooky, this is a wildly entertaining night out. Paranormal Activity isn't just a theatrical adaptation; it's a reminder that live theater, with the right team, can still find thrilling new ways to make an entire audience jump out of their seats. Remember Me Please enter your username or email address. You will receive a link to create a new password via email.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


FBI director's girlfriend gets security amid death threats, conspiracy theories
Source: WJLA    Published: 2025-11-18 18:49:29

Now 49° Wed 51° Thu 52° by ELAINE MALLON | The National News Desk WASHINGTON (TNND) — The 27-year-old long-term girlfriend of FBI Director Kash Patel will be issued a security detail in light of the growing number of death threats waged against her. “Ms. Wilkins is receiving a protective detail because she has faced hundreds of credible death threats related to her relationship with Director Patel, whom she has been dating for three years. Out of respect for her safety, we will not be providing additional details,” the FBI said in a statement. The decision to grant Wilkins' a security detail is quite unusual. Even former FBI Director Christopher Wray's wife Helen Wray didn't have her own personal security detail. She was only given security protection when she travelled with Wray, MS NOW reported. Wilkins and Patel also don't share a residence together. Wilkins lives in Nashville, Tennessee, and Patel splits his time between Washington D.C. and Las Vegas. The couple have been dating since 2023. Wilkins' security detail will consist of agents who are a part of the SWAT team assigned to the FBI Nashville's field office. Sources familiar with the FBI told MS NOW that by having these SWAT agents assigned to Wilkins it could cause delays in their response to critical situations such as mass shootings or terrorist attacks. The reported increased death threats waged against Wilkins comes amid an ongoing conspiracy theory that Wilkins is an Israeli intelligence asset, who is only dating Patel to extract information. Wilkins, who is neither Israeli or Jewish, filed a lawsuit against Kyle Seraphin, an ex-FBI turned YouTuber. He is the main conspirator behind these allegations against Wilkins. Just a few weeks ago, Seraphin revealed that Patel had used the FBI private jet to fly to see Wilkins perform at an event in Pennsylvania. FBI Directors are required to use the private FBI plane even for personal travel, but they are required to reimburse the government for the commercial price of a flight. However, Patel was previously highly critical for Wray's use of the private jet for travel. Patel took to X to defend Wilkins amid the news of his travels to see her. “I've always said — criticize me all you want. But going after the people doing great work, my personal life, or those around me is a total disgrace,” he wrote earlier this month on the social platform X. “The disgustingly baseless attacks against Alexis — a true patriot and the woman I'm proud to call my partner in life — are beyond pathetic. She is a rock-solid conservative and a country music sensation who has done more for this nation than most will in ten lifetimes. I'm so blessed she's in my life.” 2025 Sinclair, Inc.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Anna Paulina Luna Exposes Secret UFO Footage, Questions Black Congressional Budget
Source: International Business Times UK    Published: 2025-11-18 18:14:00

US Representative Anna Paulina Luna has intensified her push for transparency around UFO and UAP programmes, alleging that critical footage and data are being concealed under a classified 'black congressional budget.' Luna, who chairs the House Task Force on the Declassification of Federal Secrets, argues that lawmakers and taxpayers are being shut out of programmes that may involve advanced aircraft and unexplained phenomena. Her comments, made during interviews with The Joe Rogan Experience, FOX 13 Tampa Bay, and the Hindustan Times, have reignited debate over how the US government handles sensitive UAP material — and whether elected officials truly have oversight. Luna told Joe Rogan that she has viewed classified photographs inside a secure federal facility, claiming the objects depicted were 'not made by mankind.' She said whistle-blowers and military personnel have repeatedly described encounters with craft capable of manoeuvres that defy physics. Several sources, she insisted, referred to the operators of these craft as 'interdimensional beings' — entities capable of moving 'outside of time and space.' Luna clarified that she has not seen aliens or open portals herself, but said: 'I have seen photographic evidence in a SCIF, where I was briefed.' She suggested that descriptions from ancient texts, including missing biblical writings, may echo similar encounters. She argues that congressional oversight is being obstructed by limited access to both the data and funding behind these projects, according to Hindustan Times. In an interview with FOX 13 Tampa Bay, Luna pressed: 'Why can't we see some of these classified videos and information that seem to be operating under a black Congressional budget? ... Congress is not being given access to money that we're spending.' She added that the lack of access is both a national security and democratic accountability issue: 'If these are programs ... responsible for ... billions of dollars being lost ... that could be going towards other things.' Luna described questioning whistle-blowers and military personnel about the unknown craft, and she recounted that 'the repeated answer was that these were interdimensional beings—they defy conventional physics.' She emphasised caution, clarifying, 'I have never seen a portal open or a full alien spaceship, but I have seen photographic evidence in a secure, compartmented information facility, where I was briefed.' She suggested a possible link between ancient texts and modern phenomena, asserting that '[descriptions in the missing books of the Bible] may echo the encounters I'm investigating.' Luna recounted a confrontation at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, saying that "despite being on a congressional delegation, we were denied access to pilots and evidence." She claimed the base commander cited insufficient security authorisation. Luna said she challenged the commander, insisting that as elected officials, they are entitled to oversight. Luna's push for declassification is not without controversy. She has expressed frustration with the Pentagon and intelligence agencies, asserting that a 'protective complex' exists to keep these phenomena secret. Yet she remains determined, calling for more congressional hearings, oversight, and public accountability. Her stated goals are 'to prove that humans are not alone, and to ensure taxpayers know how money is being used in highly secretive defence programmes.' As the debate over UAP disclosure intensifies, Luna's demands spotlight the ongoing tension between national security and democratic transparency, raising questions that extend far beyond Capitol Hill. © Copyright IBTimes 2025. All rights reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


UFO Footage: Anna Paulina Luna Asks Why Data Is Hiding Under Black Congressional Budget
Source: International Business Times UK    Published: 2025-11-18 18:14:00

US Representative Anna Paulina Luna has intensified her push for transparency around UFO and UAP programmes, alleging that critical footage and data are being concealed under a classified 'black congressional budget.' Luna, who chairs the House Task Force on the Declassification of Federal Secrets, argues that lawmakers and taxpayers are being shut out of programmes that may involve advanced aircraft and unexplained phenomena. Her comments, made during interviews with The Joe Rogan Experience, FOX 13 Tampa Bay, and the Hindustan Times, have reignited debate over how the US government handles sensitive UAP material — and whether elected officials truly have oversight. Luna told Joe Rogan that she has viewed classified photographs inside a secure federal facility, claiming the objects depicted were 'not made by mankind.' She said whistle-blowers and military personnel have repeatedly described encounters with craft capable of manoeuvres that defy physics. Several sources, she insisted, referred to the operators of these craft as 'interdimensional beings' — entities capable of moving 'outside of time and space.' Luna clarified that she has not seen aliens or open portals herself, but said: 'I have seen photographic evidence in a SCIF, where I was briefed.' She suggested that descriptions from ancient texts, including missing biblical writings, may echo similar encounters. She argues that congressional oversight is being obstructed by limited access to both the data and funding behind these projects, according to Hindustan Times. In an interview with FOX 13 Tampa Bay, Luna pressed: 'Why can't we see some of these classified videos and information that seem to be operating under a black Congressional budget? ... Congress is not being given access to money that we're spending.' She added that the lack of access is both a national security and democratic accountability issue: 'If these are programs ... responsible for ... billions of dollars being lost ... that could be going towards other things.' Luna described questioning whistle-blowers and military personnel about the unknown craft, and she recounted that 'the repeated answer was that these were interdimensional beings—they defy conventional physics.' She emphasised caution, clarifying, 'I have never seen a portal open or a full alien spaceship, but I have seen photographic evidence in a secure, compartmented information facility, where I was briefed.' She suggested a possible link between ancient texts and modern phenomena, asserting that '[descriptions in the missing books of the Bible] may echo the encounters I'm investigating.' Luna recounted a confrontation at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, saying that "despite being on a congressional delegation, we were denied access to pilots and evidence." She claimed the base commander cited insufficient security authorisation. Luna said she challenged the commander, insisting that as elected officials, they are entitled to oversight. Luna's push for declassification is not without controversy. She has expressed frustration with the Pentagon and intelligence agencies, asserting that a 'protective complex' exists to keep these phenomena secret. Yet she remains determined, calling for more congressional hearings, oversight, and public accountability. Her stated goals are 'to prove that humans are not alone, and to ensure taxpayers know how money is being used in highly secretive defence programmes.' As the debate over UAP disclosure intensifies, Luna's demands spotlight the ongoing tension between national security and democratic transparency, raising questions that extend far beyond Capitol Hill. © Copyright IBTimes 2025. All rights reserved.

Petaluman's ‘supernatural experience' keeps brother's winemaking spirit alive
Source: Petaluma Argus-Courier    Published: 2025-11-18 17:49:04

eEdition Sign up for email newsletters Sign up for email newsletters eEdition TRENDING: [NOTE: The following true story was told live by Juliet Pokorny, during the West Side Stories performance that took place on Wednesday, November 12 at the Polly Klaas Community Theater. This was one of several stories shared that evening. At the end of the show, the audience selected this one as their favorite. The theme for November was “Sour Grapes.”] Have you ever had a supernatural experience? Like, maybe a voice that's not in your head, but also not a real person out there, but you hear it anyway, something in that regard? I'm about to tell a story about four supernatural experiences that happened over many years – that I didn't realize were connected until much, much later. It started when I was about 21, when I was invited to a Spiritualist Church. I don't know if you've ever been to one, but it's just like a regular church, except the ministers are psychic, and at the end, instead of putting money in a dish, you put in a note, and they give you feedback on a question that you might have. It was my first time, so I put a note in that said, “Whatever you think I need to know.” Of course, I did not think that my note would be pulled. Towards the end of their giving feedback to people, the psychic pulled a note out and I immediately knew it was mine because I could feel a pulse inside me. He looked around the room, saw me, and said, “Your brother is going to need you. Not now, not soon, but much later, and when he does, you will be there for him.” And he looked at me directly and said, “Got it?” It kind of freaked me out, but I said, “Uh huh,” and I will tell you, I then completely forgot about this message after I left, and never thought about it again. That's number one. About 25 years later, my brother calls me to tell me he has cancer. He called all of the family, each one of us separately, and when I think about how excruciating that must have been for him, because we were all upset and there he was consoling us, right? Telling us he's going to be fine, he's going to have surgery, and then radiation, and he'll be okay. So that's what we all were told. And a few months later, I get a call from one of his closest friends, Schaefer, who's a retired nurse. She's gentle, and has a sweet gentle voice, and she says, “Juliet, I need to tell you Wayne's dying, and he'll never tell you that. He has about three months to live. I want you to know this so you can make some decisions on how you want to spend time with him.” And in that moment, I hear a voice – not in my head, but not really out there, but somewhere in between that – and the voice said, “This is it. This is what the psychic was telling you. It's your time.” That's number two. I immediately went into action. I changed my schedule, and started I driving down to Watsonville two or three times a week to have dinner with him. It was pre-legal marijuana, so I made marijuana butter and I put it in all his food and we watched movies, and I brought my girls down every weekend so they could see him, right up until that last month. And his wife Helen asked me if I'd move in with them and be one of his primary caretakers, which was sad and hard, but truly one of the most beautiful gifts that could be given … to help somebody cross over. The day before he passed, his shaman came to the house. She moved everything out of his room, off his shelves, and she put these soft cloths over everything to make it very simple, and not busy when he was looking around. And then she sat down and quietly talked to him about the next things he could expect while he was about to cross over. And lastly, she took out a little tiny bag, and from it she took out some rice and some wheat or something, and she opened his hand and put it in and closed it, and she said, “You don't want to go to the other side without having something to offer them.” He nodded … and then the next day he passed, surrounded by his friends and his family, and we left his house and walked around the premises of a vineyard that he was a farmer at. He'd built this vineyard. He was a farmer. SO we walked around it and just admired the grapes on the vines – and I finally got to go home. I stood in the shower, finally alone, and then there was this voice, it was like Siri on crack or something, and it said, “You need to go across the street to your neighbor Stacey's house.” So, I got out of the shower and Dave said, “Stacey just came over. She wants you to go over to her house.” Okay. So we go over, and we sit down, and she pours two glasses of wine. And I get to talk about Wayne. I talk about what a beautiful, gentle spirit he was, how much he loved farming and how much he loved the Earth. And I told her about us walking around the vineyard after his passing and she said, “Well, what's his wine?” And I said, “Oh, you've never heard of it. It's only in, like, five-star restaurants.” She said, “Well, what's it called?” And I said, “Clos LaChance,” and she says, “Really?” And she reaches over and shows me the label. And we've been drinking my brother's wine. So that's number three. Here's number four. Cut to about two-and-a-half months ago, and Wayne's wife Helen has just passed. Her brother calls me and says, “Come to the house, and I want you to pick up any of Wayne's things that you want.” I say okay. A couple of days later, I wake up in the morning, ready to go, and it's like my brother is sitting on the bed, and he says to me, “You need to go underneath the house, and you need to get my wine.” He said, “This is where it is. You open the door, there's going to be a bike. You're going to turn left, then you're going to turn right, and that's where my wine is.” And I sort of nod. There's nobody there, but I nod. And he said, “You absolutely must insist.” And I say, out loud, “Okay!” So, I get there, and I bring my daughter Alexis. I've told her this story. We get in there and I say to Helen's brother, “Is there any chance I can go down underneath the house?” And he said, “There's nothing under there but an old bike.” My daughter says, “Well, we'd still like to get the key, if that's okay.” He says, “Sure. Go ahead.” We go down. We open the door. There's the bike. We turn left, We turn right. And lo and behold, there are, like, three cases of his wine. I go upstairs and the brother goes, “See. I told you. Nothing.” And I said, “Nope. Actually, I found three cases of his wine.” My brother, through all these years, wanted to make sure I had his wine. And it was not sour grapes. What: West Side Stories is a monthly story-slam competition hosted by Petaluma comedian Dave Pokorny, produced by he and his wife Juliet Pokorny. Selected from names in a hat, volunteers take turns telling stories based on monthly theme. The audience then chooses a winner. In December, the winners of all previous months compete in the annual Grand Slam show at the Mystic Theater. This year's Grand Slam takes place Wednesday, Dec. 3, at 7 p.m. The theme will be “Good Riddance.” When: Except for the Grand Slam in December, West Side Stories normally takes place the second Wednesday of every month at 7:30 p.m. (Schedule sometimes shifts). After the Grand Slam, the next regular WSS show will be on Wednesday, Jan.14, when the theme will be “First Things First.” Where: Mystic Theater, 21 N. Petaluma Blvd. Cost: $30, purchased in advance (this show sells out). Information: All the details, including how to purchase tickets, can be found at WestSideStoriesPetaluma.com. Copyright © 2025 MediaNews Group
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Cloudflare Outage Before Epstein Files Vote Sparks Conspiracy Theories
Source: Newsweek    Published: 2025-11-18 17:32:00

Published Nov 18, 2025 at 12:32 PM EST News Reporter Conspiracy theories flooded social media when Cloudflare suffered an outage early Tuesday, causing problems for users on platforms including X, Donald Trump's Truth Social platform and ChatGPT. In an email shared with Newsweek, a spokesperson for the internet services company said: "Many of Cloudflare's services experienced a significant outage today beginning around 10:20 UTC. It was fully resolved at 14:30 UTC. The root cause of the outage was a configuration file that is automatically generated to manage threat traffic." The issue was fixed in six hours, but that didn't stop the conspiracy theorists, who linked the outage with the Epstein files vote in Congress. The outage occurred the same morning that the House of Representatives was preparing to hold a vote on the release of files relating to Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender found dead in a cell in August, 2019, while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Though his death was ruled a suicide, it has long been at the center of conspiracy theories due to his well-documented connections to public and powerful figures, including President Donald Trump. The outcome of the procedural votes and debates on the Epstein Files Transparency Act, authored by representatives Thomas Massie, R-Ky, and Ro Khanna, D-Calif, could have significant implications for transparency regarding one of the most high-profile criminal cases in recent decades, and it marks a rare bipartisan push for greater government disclosure. The Cloudflare outage occurring on the same day as the vote sparked conspiracy theories online, and social media users attempted to draw a connection between the two events. One post on X, from the account @GermanicFren, which has over 50,000 followers, reads "Oh you're gonna vote on releasing the epstein files??? Shut down the internet!!" Another post, from the account @leave_not_liv reads "if you're having issues with this app or other websites today, it's because cloudflare is having a software issue causing mass outages today interesting that this is happening as the Epstein files goes to a vote and a potential release may happen." A spokesperson for Cloudflare, which delivers multiple websites on its global cloud network, told Newsweek the configuration file that caused the outage "grew beyond an expected size of entries and triggered a crash in the software system that handles traffic for a number of Cloudflare's services." The account @Patriot7712pt3, which has over 10,000 followers on X, posted: "It's no coincidence Cloudflare went down right before the vote on releasing the Epstein case files." The account @iArtSoometimes, which has over 20,000 followers on X: "Cloudflare outage same day as Epstein House vote…coincidence? I THINK NOT!" Cloudflare, in a statement to Newsweek over email: "To be clear, there is no evidence that this was the result of an attack or caused by malicious activity. We expect that some Cloudflare services will be briefly degraded as traffic naturally spikes post incident but we expect all services to return to normal in the next few hours. A detailed explanation will be posted soon on blog.cloudfare.com. Given the importance of Cloudflare's services, any outage is unacceptable. We apologize to our customers and the internet in general for letting you down today. We will learn from today's incident and improve." Procedural votes and debates were scheduled to get underway in the House at 10 a.m. © 2025 Newsweek Digital LLC
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


How to Tap Into Your Psychic Powers, According to Celebrities' Favorite Medium
Source: thecut.com    Published: 2025-11-18 17:00:44

Find this story in your account's ‘Saved for Later' section. Find this story in your account's ‘Saved for Later' section. Things you buy through our links may earn Vox Media a commission Save this article to read it later. Find this story in your account's ‘Saved for Later' section. Laura Lynne Jackson says she was 11 years old when she discovered her psychic abilities. One summer day while she was swimming and playing with her siblings, she remembers, Jackson's mother said she was heading out to visit their grandparents. Jackson says she was seized by a sudden sense of panic; she knew she had to go with her mom and see her grandfather. They had a wonderful day together, and two days later, he was admitted into the hospital. She never saw him again. She says she was riddled with guilt: Was I complicit in his death? Her mom pushed back. “No normal kid is supposed to know when somebody they love so profoundly is going to die,” Jackson says. “But she said to me, ‘Laura, no part of you is dark or cursed or broken. This is just an extra ability you have, and it's a beautiful part of you. You don't need to be scared of it. Just accept it and embrace it.'” It took decades, but eventually Jackson did just that. She studied to become an English teacher, but after she had her first daughter, Jackson says she couldn't ignore her gift anymore and she started studying to be a certified medium. Now, she's one of the world's most famous psychics. Her clients include Gwyneth Paltrow and Kim Kardashian, and she has written two New York Times best-selling books — perhaps most famously Signs: The Secret Language of the Universe, which shows readers how to recognize messages from loved ones who have died and, most recently, Guided: The Secret Path to an Illuminated Life, which was published on November 11. (How did she feel, I wondered, about the TikTok video Kardashian posted after our interview saying that four unnamed psychics were “fucking full of shit” because they told her she was going to pass the bar exam and she didn't? Jackson's representatives declined to provide a comment.) In Guided, Jackson encourages her readers to be open to messages and guidance from the other side. In order for these signs to even reach us in the first place, she says we have to remain receptive to the possibility that there are forces greater than us who are wanting and willing to give us whatever help we're looking for. We just have to ask. I took that invitation literally and called up Jackson at her home on Long Island to ask about her new book, her backstory, and what she'd say to the skeptics among us. One of the major messages in your books is that we all have psychic abilities and are able to connect with the other side. What do you mean by that?I'm actually a huge skeptic; I'm always raising an eyebrow at certain things. But I want to normalize this because this is a very inherent part of all of us. We have this doorway within us that's so beautiful — that connects us to our “Team of Light,” connects us to our soul, our higher self — and the guidance is right there inside. I think what happens to most people is they distance themselves from their spiritual self. They distance themselves from trusting their intuition. That's where I come in. You do not need to go to a psychic or a medium or a psychic medium or anybody to open that up. You don't need anybody to activate it for you. I still see myself as a teacher. I happen to be a psychic medium, but I'm teaching people how to access this inside of themselves. The No. 1 thing you just have to do is you have to set the intention in your thoughts. You don't have to say it out loud — you can if you'd like to — but you just set the intention with your Team of Light and you say, I'm ready. I'm open. Please guide me. Show me my abilities. Help lead me to the people and the experiences and the books and the situations that I'm meant to experience on my journey to help open me up. Once you open your mind and your heart to this truth, magical things happen. What do you mean by “Team of Light”?I believe we all have a Team of Light on the other side. It's made up of three parts: It's God energy, it's what I refer to as spirit guides — throughout history, these might be referred to as guardian angels: these angelic beings who are your teachers and your mentors, who your soul contracts with before you come here to Earth School, and they're just there to guide you — and then the third part of that is your Team of Light on the other side. How do you suppose people can connect to that?Light energy can manipulate small metallic objects, like putting coins in our path — pennies, dimes, or nickels. They love to also mess with electrical devices, anything from making the lights go wonky to shutting the TV on and off. They will send creatures that navigate this world using electromagnetic fields, like butterflies, dragonflies, deer, fox, and every type of bird there is. Sometimes they'll send their initials or their names on license plates. They'll put stuff in your social-media feed that they want you to experience or that's going to remind you of them. That's what they're creating with you, but in order to develop this language together, you need to ask for something really specific. I always encourage people to create four different ways the other side can communicate with them. Pick an animal, but I always say make it a little different because when you get your animal, your logical mind is going to be like, Oh, that's a coincidence. That was too easy. Pick a number sequence. Pick a phrase — it could be anything that was important to you from when you were younger or one that just pops in your mind right now. Then pick a song. And now you have created four different ways your Team of Light can communicate with you. I think the greatest way we can honor those signs and that communication and that connection is to tell someone else about our sign story or to tell somebody else about the guidance we felt. That's how we honor that ongoing relationship. What would you say to someone who might be skeptical and think those signs are just, well, coincidences?That's a great thing, that they are questioning themselves, because that means they are a seeker and they're a critical thinker. I think that we have been taught to fear and doubt any spiritual experience we have. We have been taught to disempower ourselves by labeling it “woo-woo,” by being scared of it, by not giving it credence, and by not honoring it. If people say to themselves, I asked for this sign, and I got it — could that be a coincidence?, I always say to those people, “Ask for another one, and you're going to get it.” Just keep trying the language. Change the sign; ask for a new sign. You're going to get that. I think what happens for people when they keep having these experiences — they have to own it as their own truth. I think it can be so beautiful when we have this reawakening. Celebrities like Kim Kardashian and Gwyneth Paltrow blurbed Guided. How did you connect with them? I've never advertised my services in all my life. The only way you could ever find me is if somebody had a reading with me or if you came to the Forever Family Foundation, where I volunteered. One thing that I've always been aware of is what a gift it is to have a platform and help the world. Every single person you just mentioned, and everybody I have been so blessed to get to know, I met organically. It was never anything I tried to make happen. I was guided to those people — or you could say they were guided to me. I know there are always perceptions about outward persona, tabloid fodder, this or that, but I will tell you everybody that you've mentioned is so loving, kind, and supportive. So many people think Hollywood is vapid, but no — it's not. People are so loving and kind to one another. It's incredible. I think, also, because they've had their own experiences with the other side, they know it's the truth — and so they're going to share that to help others. I've always said the greatest part of my life journey is who I've met along the way. That doesn't just mean celebrities; there are so many relationships I hold sacred that I've met through this work that have become such a big part of my heart. I think we're guided to the people on the path we're meant to know. In Guided, you emphasize that in order to receive signs and messages from the universe and the other side, we have to start by being open to it. What tangible steps do you think people can take to do this?The most important step to living a guided life is just by simply setting your intention in your thoughts that you want to be guided. It is that simple. Our thoughts are more powerful than we can even fathom, and that every thought we have, we're either putting more light into the world or more darkness. Step two is opening your mind and your heart to being able to recognize the guidance and being able to tell your logical mind to sit down, be quiet, and honor the truth of that guidance. One way you can do that is by talking to others, by telling your story, saying, “I experienced this. I want to tell you about my connection.” Just those two little things: Setting the intention, and then being in a state of openness to recognize and receive that guidance, is phenomenal. It can change small things or it can change big things in your life. You can ask for guidance on everything, from being guided to a good parking spot to being guided into your career change or the next relationship. Guided is about what happens when you get rid of the fear — when you master the doubt and you are in a state of connectivity with your Team of Light and you trust what you're getting. That's when the magic happens. By submitting your email, you agree to our Terms and Privacy Notice and to receive email correspondence from us. Things you buy through our links may earn Vox Media a commission Have an Account?
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Cynthia Erivo Gets Extraterrestrial in Balenciaga, Ariana Grande Marries Light and Dark in Schiaparelli and More at the ‘Wicked: For Good' NYC Premiere
Source: Yahoo    Published: 2025-11-18 15:57:41

Manage your account Theatricality was the fashion memo for the “Wicked: For Good” premiere in New York City on Monday night, featuring designer looks worn by Oscar-nominated stars Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande and more. Pieces by Balenciaga, Schiaparelli, Givenchy and more featured on the red carpet, with method-dressing approaches and ornate design. WWD breaks down those looks and more ahead. More from WWD Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande Bring 'Wicked' Method Dressing in Vintage Dior and Givenchy to the Governors Awards 2025 Red Carpet Ariana Grande Returns to Her Signature Glinda Whimsy in Custom Thom Browne at 'Wicked: For Good' Singapore Premiere Ariana Grande Doubles Down on Christian Louboutin Cassia Platforms on 'Wicked: For Good' Press Tour Cynthia Erivo channeled the dark side of her character, Elphaba, in a theatrical black gown from Balenciaga. The dress featured a drop waist silhouette with a voluminous skirt. The bodice was fitted, with fabric contrast from a soft tone to a glossy sheen. Twirling feather motifs featured along the bustline, while the long sleeves included a glove element to frame the Oscar-nominated actress' nails. Makeup for Erivo's look was provided by Joanna Simkin, with nail tech by Shea Osei. The actress' look was curated by stylist Jason Bolden. Ariana Grande turned to a design by Schiaparelli's creative director, Daniel Roseberry. The custom haute couture dress featured a ballgown silhouette with a black ruched crepe and satin bustier, which laced up the back. The bodice also included delicate side bows and the Italian fashion house's signature keyhole embroidery at the bustier. The voluminous skirt was crafted with 200 meters of silk organza and tulle split into 20 ruffles. Grande accessorized her look with jewelry pieces by Swarovski, for which she serves as a global brand ambassador. Makeup artist Michael Anthony and hairstylist Alyx Liu provided glam for the actress, with image architect Law Roach curating the Oscar-nominated star's look. Michelle Yeoh wore the voluminous final look from Givenchy's fall 2025 ready-to-wear collection designed by Sarah Burton. The ample frame of the dress created a quasi-bubbled effect in a light yellow shade with layers of tulle fabric. Yeoh accessorized with a bold statement necklace with her hair coiffed in a pixie cut. Marissa Bode opted for a design by Anne Barge for her red carpet attire. The strapless dress evoked the Wicked Witch of the West in its dark shade of forest green. Styled by Alexandra Mandelkorn, Bode accentuated her “Wicked”-inspired attire with a pair of silver sparkling Christian Louboutin shoes akin to the memorable ruby red slippers from “The Wizard of Oz.” Colman Domingo wore a look by Dolce & Gabbana. The Oscar-nominated actor's attire wholly evoked The Cowardly Lion from “The Wizard of Oz,” with a statement furry coat with long sleeves and an exaggerated lapel. Domingo also wore a flowing cream shirt, light beige pants, and brown loafers with tassels. The actor's look was curated by styling team Wayman Bannerman and Micah McDonald. Jeff Goldblum channeled his Wizard of Oz character in a custom Prada look. Harkening back to the 1939 costumes for the original “Wizard of Oz,” Goldblum's look, styled by Andrew T. Vottero, featured a green vest atop an emerald dress shirt, coordinated with a velvet blue, long-sleeve coat. A gold watch accessorized the waist of Goldblum's attire, which was capped off with a pair of neutral gray trousers. “Wicked: For Good” is the sequel to the 2024 film based on the Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, which follows the relationship between Glinda, The Good Witch of the North, played by Grande, and Elphaba, The Wicked Witch of the West, played by Erivo, as Dorothy Gale crash lands into Oz. The film hits theaters Friday. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Machine learning framework can scan for signs of extraterrestrial life
Source: Phys.org    Published: 2025-11-18 14:54:32

by PNAS Nexus edited by Gaby Clark, reviewed by Robert Egan Visualization of the distribution of compounds in meteoritic samples and terrestrial geologic samples and the regression coefficients of the logistic regression model trained in LifeTracer. Credit: Saeedi et al. A machine learning framework can distinguish molecules made by biological processes from those formed through non-biological processes and could be used to analyze samples returned by current and future planetary missions. The findings are published in the journal PNAS Nexus. José C. Aponte, Amirali Aghazadeh, and colleagues analyzed eight carbonaceous meteorites and ten terrestrial geologic samples using two-dimensional gas chromatography coupled with high-resolution time-of-flight mass spectrometry. Using this data, the authors developed LifeTracer, a computational framework that processes mass spectrometry data and applies machine learning to identify patterns distinguishing abiotic from biotic origins. A logistic regression model trained on compound-level features achieved over 87% accuracy in classifying samples as meteoritic or terrestrial. The analysis identified 9,475 peaks in meteorite samples and 9,070 in terrestrial samples, with statistically significant differences between the two sample types in molecular weight distributions and retention times, which describes how long it takes the compound to move through the chromatograph's two columns. Organic compounds in meteorite samples showed significantly lower retention times, consistent with higher volatility in abiotically formed materials. The framework identified polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and alkylated variants as key predictive features, with naphthalene emerging as the most predictive compound for abiotic samples. According to the authors, the approach enables scalable, unbiased biosignature detection and could be a powerful tool for interpreting complex organic mixtures that will be returned by current and future planetary sample return missions. More information: Daniel Saeedi et al, Discriminating abiotic and biotic organics in meteorite and terrestrial samples using machine learning on mass spectrometry data, PNAS Nexus (2025). DOI: 10.1093/pnasnexus/pgaf334. academic.oup.com/pnasnexus/art … 4/11/pgaf334/8323799 Journal information: PNAS Nexus Provided by PNAS Nexus Use this form if you have come across a typo, inaccuracy or would like to send an edit request for the content on this page. Neither your address nor the recipient's address will be used for any other purpose. The information you enter will appear in your e-mail message and is not retained by Tech Xplore in any form.
